subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: get your news in QS!
msgSnippet: ... The code is being developed on sourceforge, so it is open source. http://sourceforge.net/projects/quikscript/ I haven t committed all the latest code yet,
messageBody:
Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
>
>
> Excellent work, Paul!
>
> I think I sense a new open-source project team taking shape here. Are
> you willing to contribute your code, Paul? In addition to the ideas
> already offered, I'd like to see settings for at least two different
> accents: General American and RP (if that is not adequate, then
> several choices to represent accents of the British Isles). For more
> discrimating users, there should be a detailed settings page where the
> user can choose the QS letter corresponding to each lexical set. This
> page would look very similar to the figures Anthony put together with
> gray and black words for the lexical sets.
>
> As has already been pointed out, code development is the minor part of
> the work for such a project. The main effort would require a team of
> database curators with at least one person taking the lead for each
> major accent. It should be stressed that these people need not be
> software developers.
>
> The CMU Dictionary provides an excellent starting point for General
> American. Is there a similarly available resource for RP?
>

The code is being developed on sourceforge, so it is open source.

http://sourceforge.net/projects/quikscript/

I haven't committed all the latest code yet, and some of the code are
libraries just on my machine, but since there is an interest by others,
I'll add that code as well.

I can add anyone who wants to become a developer. The whole process
involves basically two steps: getting a suitable web page, and
translating the text. I think the translation part is developed with
care, but the other part is a bit of a hack, but so far it works.

The dictionary is the CMU dictionary, which may be based on American
pronunciation, though I was under the impression it was based on
British. The translation part loads the main dictionary in, then loads
my personal dictionary in, which overrides the main one where they
overlap, so that may account for the words seeming American. I'm not
sure. (The program can load in as many dictionaries as needed.)

However, I am under the impression that with lexical sets, used with
care, we should all of us more or less spell words the same. Because I
had in mind transliterating works like this, I have kind of advocated
for some standardization of QS. Otherwise we would need one text for
Americans, one for British, and one for Australians.

Paul
